construction: Create a model for the fixed-bias transistor amp shown in the schematic.  Nodes for the signal generator have been constructed already.  Assume RB is 180Kohms, RL is 1Kohm, and VCC is 10 volts.  For the transistor, assume beta is 100, the knee voltage of the BE junction is 0.7 volts, and the resistance of the BE junction when forward biased is 100 ohms.  Graph the output voltage, that is, the voltage at the collector.

givenModelNodes.name: V across RB
givenModelNodes.description: Voltage drop across base bias resistor

givenModelNodes.name: V across RL
givenModelNodes.description: Voltage drop across collector load resistor

givenModelNodes.name: R of BE junction
givenModelNodes.description: Resistance of BE when forward biased

givenModelNodes.name: I of signal
givenModelNodes.description: Current into base due to signal
givenModelNodes.explanation: Because the transistor amplifies the base current, but the signal is given in volts, we need to know the resistance of the base-emitter junction in order to see how much base current the signal voltage will cause.  I'm just guessing 100 ohms for the forward-biased base-emitter junction.  If there were an emitter resistor, this assumption may not be necessary.

givenModelNodes.name: I into base
givenModelNodes.description: Current into base including both signal and bias
givenModelNodes.explanation: To calculate the current into the base, we use superposition.  One voltage source is the base bias, and the other is the signal.
